title: 111_s3238
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The tragic deaths on September 11, 2001, have forever changed the nation. The heroic actions of officers, emergency workers, and government employees who responded to the attacks on the World Trade Center in New York City are acknowledged. The heroic actions of responders to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon on September 11, 2001, are acknowledged. The responders to the attack on the Pentagon in Washington, DC, and the passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 took heroic actions to prevent further casualties and ensure the safety of innocent Americans and American institutions. The passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 took heroic action to prevent the aircraft from being used as a weapon. It is fitting to recognize their sacrifice with an appropriate medal. SEC. 3. FALLEN HEROES OF 9/11 CONGRESSIONAL MEDALS. The President is authorized to award a "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals, Flight 93 National Memorial Project, National September 11 Memorial and Museum, and Pentagon Memorial Project. The Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal is awarded to honor the sacrifice made by individuals on September 11, 2001. The medal designs are struck by the Secretary of the Treasury for presentations at the Flight 93 National Memorial Project, National September 11 Memorial and Museum, and Pentagon Memorial Project. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 medal designs to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attack at the World Trade Center, including civilians, public safety officers, emergency workers, and the passengers and crew of Flight 11 and United Airlines Flight 175. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 medal designs to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attack at the World Trade Center, Flight 93 in Pennsylvania, and the Pentagon. The Secretary of the Treasury will consult with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties to determine the design of medals honoring those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Flight 93 in Pennsylvania, and the Pentagon. The Secretary of the Treasury will consult with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties to determine the design of silver and gold medals for individuals who died as a direct result of terrorism after September 11, 2001. The medals authorized for individuals who died as a direct result of terrorism after September 11, 2001, will be silver for subsection (a)(1) and gold for subsection (a)(2) through (4). Eligibility for the medal is determined by the Secretary in consultation with other relevant officials. SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS. The Secretary will create bronze duplicates of medals for officers, emergency workers, and employees of government agencies, to be displayed at their duty stations in memory of those assigned there on September 11, 2001. In 2001, bronze duplicates of medals will be displayed at duty stations in memory of officers, emergency workers, and government employees who responded to the 9/11 attacks and perished as a result of terrorism. SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF LISTS OF RECIPIENTS. Before the end of the 120-day period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will establish lists of individuals eligible for a medal under section 3(c)(1) and eligible recipients of a duplicate medal under section 4, for the period from September 11, 2001, to the date of enactment. The Secretary will establish lists of individuals eligible for a medal under section 3(c)(1) and eligible recipients of a duplicate medal under section 4, consulting various victim lists for the period from September 11, 2001, to the date of enactment. The Secretary will consult victim lists to establish eligibility for a medal under section 3(c)(1) and for duplicate medals under section 4. Determinations made are final and not subject to judicial review. The Secretary will consult victim lists to establish eligibility for medals under section 3(c)(1) and for duplicate medals under section 4. Lists established are not subject to judicial review. If an individual becomes eligible for a medal, the Secretary will promptly add their name to the appropriate list. The Secretary may sell duplicate bronze medals to the public to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are considered national medals.
